msItem.filiation: Guglielmetti and Keats-Rohan consider this manuscript to be the direct source of two other manuscripts, one of which is now Oxford, Bodleian Library, Barlow 48, from Cirencester Abbey.

msItem.note: Partial index in a 14th-century cursive; pen trials

supportDesc.foliation: Foliated in modern pencil, skipping a page after fol. 140 (140bis); 158 skipped in numeration.

collation.signatures: Signature xxvi at end of gathering 26 (at foot of fol. 206v), in a different hand.

layoutDesc.layout: Ruled in plummet, with rules in the centre of top and outer margins, used for aligning running heads and marginal labels. Line spacing 6–7 mm. Pricked on all edges (though usually trimmed on the outside) for frame and individual lines

handDesc.handNote: Written in protogothic script, somewhat vertically compressed, end of the twelfth century. Ascenders lengthened on top line.

decoDesc.decoNote: New books open with illuminated initials decorated in gold leaf, potentially added somewhat later: fol. 1ra, 3-line S; fol. 2rb, I in the margin, depicting three men with scrolls; fol. 4vb (book 1), I in the margin, showing men fighting with animals; fol. 17vb (book 2), 5-line O, showing a teacher and pupil; fol. 45ra (book 3), 3-line H, with ascender extending into the margin; fol. 60vb (book 4), 4-line A, dragon being slain by a man in his mouth; fol. 73rb (book 5), 4-line N, man holding back the mouth of a dragon and brandishing a sword; fol. 96va (book 6), 5-line N, two dragons with foliage; fol. 119ra (book 7), 5-line E, two men in discussion with town in background; fol. 155rb (book 8), 5-line S, four men on a ship with a dragon figurehead, being blown by the face of a wind. Chapters open with two-line Arabesque initials, alternating between red, blue, and sometimes green, occasionally with penwork in the opposite colour (always paring green with red). Marginal labels in red or green, with a border in the opposite colour. Large marginal paraph marks in black and red occasionally added (e.g. fol. 97r).

additions.p: Corrections from two or three thirteenth-century hands, one of which (e.g. on fol. 123r) appears to be that of Walter de Melida, who was also responsible for part of the Cirencester copy of this manuscript, now Barlow 48.
Marginal additions in a 14th-century gothic cursive that also began an index at the end, fol. 209v.
Marginal additions in a 15th- or 16th-century humanist hand.
Added paper leaf, fol. iiv: seventeenth-century notes on John of Salisbury, with references to John Leland, John Pitts.

binding.p: Stamped brown leather over boards, 17th-century, rebacked.

history.origin: Written at Malmesbury Abbey: the second abbot Robert referred to at fol. 209rb was Robert of Melun, who served from 1189/90 to 1205. A Salamon occurs as scriptor at Malmesbury in 1193 (see Registrum Malmesburiense, Rolls Series 1, p. 461).
history.provenance: Richardus Ramsæus possidet (fol. 209rb, middle of the 16th cent.).
Wyllyam Fyttz (fol. 209v, middle of the 16th cent., not necessarily an owner).
history.acquisition: Given to the Bodleian by Thomas Barlow: on fol. 1r, his motto, Αἰὲν ἀριστεύειν and autograph inscription Lib. Thomæ Barlow è Coll. Reg. Oxon. socii. Anno Christi m.dc.xxxiii.
